title: Employers tricking workers out of sick pay allowance - the tactics to watch for and your full rights explained
text:
Employers tricking workers out of sick pay allowance - the tactics to watch for and your full rights explained A number of firms are trying to dodge sick pay for people who are too ill to work by withdrawing shifts and even sacking them - this is what to do if it happens to you Share Comments By Emma Munbodh 17:39, 27 FEB 2017 Money One of the most common tactics saw firms cancelling people’s shifts after they called in sick (Photo: getty) money Employers are tricking staff out of their sick pay allowance by using tactics such as taking them off rotas and cutting their hours, an investigation has found.
Citizens Advice uncovered firms penalising people who are too ill to work by reducing wages, demanding GP evidence for minor illnesses, and sacking staff to avoid the compulsory statutory sick pay (SSP).
The charity, which says advice for sick pay peaks in February - helped more than 1,800 workers this time last year - 11% more on average than the rest of the year.
Read More Do you have to tell your boss you're ill? Sick pay rules - what are they? People are entitled to be paid if they’re off work for four days or more, and earn more than £112 a week.
However, evidence from Citizens Advice found that some employers are exploiting confusion around the rules to avoid coughing up.
One of the most common tactics implemented saw firms cancelling people’s shifts after they'd called in sick, to appear as though they weren't meant to be working in the first place.
In most cases, people who have their hours changed for example due to sickness, will often still be eligible - but don’t realise that they are.
Read More Employment rights National UK living wage to rise in April Understanding zero-hour contracts What to tell your boss you're ill What to do if you're made redundant Can I take the day off because of snow? Should I get paid for my time commuting? Pay rights Workplace discrimination over of weight Sneaky tactics used by employers Cancelling people’s shifts after they call in sick, so that it looks like they aren't meant to be working
Reducing people’s wages and downplaying their working hours so they don’t meet the £112 earnings threshold
Saying that they need a GP note as evidence they’re ill for even a few days off, even though people can self-certify for up to 7 days
Refusing to fill in a HMRC sick pay form, which would make employers explain their reasons for not paying
Sacking people rather than paying them
In one instance, Citizens Advice found one man who worked five days a week in a factory, but had a casual contract stating he worked just seven hours.
When he was off sick, his employer tried to deny him sick pay on the basis he didn't work enough hours or earn enough, although in practice he did.
A carer on a zero hour contract contacted Citizens Advice for help after she was signed off for seven days for a work-related injury.
Her employer cancelled her shifts for the next three weeks in an attempt to argue that she wasn't due to be working - whereas in reality she’d already committed to the work.
Citizens Advice chief executive Gillian Guy said: "Sick pay is a basic right which many workers are entitled to.
"Although some employers make genuine mistakes working out whether workers are eligible, others are trying to confuse people about their rights so they can get away with not paying up.
“Getting paid time off to recover from illness is not only important for people’s health, but also prevents them from being left with a hole in their finances that they can struggle to recover from."
How does sick pay work? Employees are legally entitled to statutory sick pay (SSP) for up to 28 weeks - this is currently £88.45 per week .
SSP doesn't start until the fourth day that you're off sick, so you might not get paid anything for the first three days.
Some workers receive what’s called contractual sick pay on top of SSP, so they’ll receive full pay - or something similar - for a certain number of weeks. SSP is paid by your employer in the same way that you normally get paid.
A typical sick pay scheme usually starts after a minimum period of service, for example, a three month probationary period you can find details of this in your contract.
Who is entitled to sick pay? (Photo: Getty) You don’t have to be a full time employee to get statutory sick pay (SSP). You can also get it if you’re on a fixed term contract, work part-time, work through an agency or on a zero-hours contract.
You qualify if:
You normally earn more than £112 a week.
You’re sick for more than four days in a row, including non-working days. You’ll get sick pay from the fourth working day of your illness, unless you've been off sick in the last eight weeks - then you’ll get paid from the first working day.
You follow your employer’s’ rules about reporting sickness absence. Most employers ask you to provide a sick note if you’re off sick for more than seven days for example. If there aren't any rules, make sure you call in sick as soon as you need to take time off work, and ask if there’s anything else you need to do to record your sickness.
Do I need to show proof of sickness? Your employer may set out how you should tell them that you are sick, ringing in before a certain time of the day, for example.
Usually you will be able to self-certify for a week of illness; beyond that a medical note may be required.
Read More Do you have to tell your boss you're ill? My employer insists I'm not entitled (Photo: Getty) If your boss insists that you aren't entitled to sick pay - but you feel you are, ask them to fill in the government sick pay form explaining their reasons.
Once you’ve got it, contact HM revenue and customs (HMRC). They will ask you about your circumstances and make a decision about whether you are owed sick pay or not.
If HMRC decide that you are owed sick pay, your employer will be ordered to pay up. If they still refuse, contact the ACAS early conciliation service who will negotiate with your employer.
Time off to care for a sick dependant (Photo: Getty) You can take time off to care for a sick dependant. However, your employer does not have to pay you for this time unless your contract says they must.
What happens after four weeks? (Photo: Getty) After four weeks, you’ll be considered "long-term sick". Your boss may be able to make you redundant, but only after trying to help you get back into work.
If you’re still sick after 28 weeks, your employer should give you a form to claim Employment and Support Allowance instead.
